Australian [[Pop music|pop]] [[singer]] who has released nineteen [[studio album]]s, three [[extended play]]s, nineteen [[compilation album]]s, five [[live album]]s, seventeen [[home video|video albums]], seventy-four [[single (music)|singles]], twenty-five [[music video]]s and twelve [[soundtrack]]s.{{cite encyclopedia|last=McFarlane|first=Ian|authorlink=Ian 2009}} Aside from solo releases, Farnham has recorded duets with other solo artists or with bands. Farnham was vocalist for The Mavericks from 1964, by late 1965 he had joined Strings Unlimited, In 1966, they recorded a three-track demo tape with Farnham on vocals, Stewart Male on [[lead guitar]], Barry Roy on [[rhythm guitar]], Mike Foenander on [[keyboard instrument|keyboards]] and Peter Foggie on [[drum kit|drums]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.johnfarnham.info/biography/biography.htm|title=John Farnham biography|publisher=johnfarnham.info|accessdate=8 October 2009}} [[Talent manager]], Darryl Sambell, saw Strings Unlimited perform on 29 April 1967 and encouraged Farnham to go solo. Farnham recorded an advertising jingle, "Susan Jones", for an airline, [[Ansett Australia|Ansett-ANA]], and signed a contract with [[EMI]]. Farnham's debut single was a [[novelty song]], "[[Sadie (The Cleaning Lady)]]", released in November 1967. His debut extended play, ''[[Johnny Farnham (EP)|Johnny Farnham]]'', followed in December, and his single peaked at #1 on the Australian [[Go-Set#Go-Set Australian National Charts|National Singles Charts]] for five weeks in early 1968.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sitelevel.com/query.go?crid=727d92946b2bcd67&query=Farnham|work=Go-Set|title=''Go-Set'' search engine results for "Farnham"|publisher=Waverley Press|accessdate=4 October 2009}} NOTE: ''Go-Set'' published its National Singles Charts from October 1966 until August 1974, they were compiled by [[Ed Nimmervoll]]. Selling 180 000 copies in Australia, "Sadie" was the highest selling single by an Australian artist of the decade.{{Cite book|title=1001 Australians You Should Know|last=Creswell |first=Toby|authorlink=Toby Creswell|coauthors=Samantha Trenoweth|year=2006|publisher=Pluto Press|location=[[North Melbourne, Victoria|North Melbourne, Vic]]|isbn=9781864033618|accessdate=9 October 2009}} Farnham's debut studio album, ''[[Sadie (album)|Sadie]]'' was issued in April 1968. Other #1 singles are "[[Raindrops Keep Fallin' on My Head]]" in 1969–1970, "[[You're the Voice]]" in 1986 and "Age of Reason" in 1988; and his #1 albums are ''[[Whispering Jack]]'' in 1986–1987, ''[[Age of Reason (album)|Age of Reason]]'' in 1988, ''[[Chain Reaction (John Farnham album)|Chain Reaction]]'' in 1990, ''[[Then Again (John Farnham album)|Then Again]]'' in 1993, ''[[Anthology 1: Greatest Hits 1986-1997]]'' in 1997, ''[[33â (album)|33â]]'' in 2000 and ''[[The Last Time (album)|The Last Time]]'' in 2002.{{Cite web|url=http://www.musicaustralia.org/apps/MA?function=showDetail¤tMapsRecord=ANL:MA~1133493023893&itemSeq=1&total=32&&returnFunction=viewTheme&&sessionId= |title=Farnham |publisher=Music Australia |accessdate=9 October 2009}} ==Studio albums== {| class="wikitable" ! rowspan="2"|Year ! rowspan="2" width="210"|Album details ! colspan="6"|Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2"|[[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]

It entered ''[[Go-Set]]'' National Top 40 on 13 December 1967 and peaked at #1 in January–February for five weeks.{{Cite web|url=http://www.poparchives.com.au/gosetcharts/singles.html|work=Go-Set|title=''Go-Set'' Magazine's Number One Singles in Australia 1966–1974|publisher=Waverley Press|accessdate=4 October 2009}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sitelevel.com/query.go?crid=727d92946b2bcd67&query=%22Sadie+The+Cleaning+Lady%22|work=Go-Set|title=''Go-Set'' search engine results for "Sadie (The Cleaning Lady)"|publisher=Waverley Press|accessdate=5 September 2009}} On the [[Kent Music Report]], "Sadie" was #1 for six weeks. :B.{{Note|B}}"[[Underneath the Arches (song)|Underneath the Arches]]" / "Friday Kind of Monday" was released as a [[A-side and B-side#Double A-side|Double A-sided]] single in May 1968. "Underneath the Arches" was a non-album release, while "Friday Kind of Monday" was from the EP, ''Johnny Farnham'', in December 1967 and subsequently appeared on the LP, ''Sadie'' in April 1968. :C.{{Note|C}}"Jamie" / "I Don't Want to Love You" was released as a Double A-sided single in July 1968. "I Don't Want to Love You" appeared on ''Johnny Farnham'' EP in December 1967. Both A-sides subsequently appeared on the LP, ''Everybody Oughta Sing a Song'' in November 1968. :D.{{Note|D}}"[[Raindrops Keep Fallin' on My Head]]" was a [[cover version|cover]] of the [[B J Thomas]] song, it was released in November 1969, in early 1970 it peaked at #1 on both the ''Go-Set'' Singles Chart and Kent Music Report Singles Chart for seven weeks. :E.{{Note|E}}"Baby, Without You" and the related album, ''Together'', has Farnham teamed with [[Allison Durbin]]. Both Farnham as 'King of Pop' (1969–1973) and Durbin as 'Most Popular Female Performer' (1969–1971) were the most popular personalities in reader polls for the [[Australian pop music awards#1967–1978: King of Pop Awards|King of Pop Awards]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.milesago.com/Performance/kingofpop.htm |title=''TV Week'' "King of Pop" Awards |publisher=Milesago |year=2002 |accessdate=7 October 2009 }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.televisionau.com/top40tv.htm |title=Top 40 TV |publisher=Televisionau.com |accessdate=7 October 2009}} :F.{{Note|F}}''[[Charlie Girl]]'' is a [[Musical theatre|stage musical]] which had Farnham as the male lead in the 1971 Australian production.{{Cite book|url=http://books.google.com.au/books?id=ELACebeQEgcC |title=The dictionary of performing arts in Australia |last=Atkinson |first=Ann |coauthors=Linsay Knight, Margaret McPhee |publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]] |year=1996|isbn=9781863738989 |accessdate=7 October 2009 }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ausstage.edu.au/indexdrilldown.jsp?xcid=59&f_event_id=30763|title=''Charlie Girl'' |publisher=AusStage |accessdate=7 October 2009}} The Australian cast released the stage album, ''Charlie Girl'', which included the single, "Charlie Girl";
